text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
ADI IGNATIUS: Hi, everyone.

I'm Adi Ignatius,
editor-in-chief
of Harvard Business Review.

And this is episode
3 of HBR Quarantined.

We have been working from home,
on lockdown, in quarantine
for-- this is the ninth week.

And we just thought a lot of
you are in the same position.

So we created this show
to talk about issues--

the fallout from
COVID-19 on the economy,

on business, on what in the
world the economy and what work

will look like when we
all get back to work.

So we have a special guest
star today, Arianna Huffington,

who is co-founder and the
force behind Huffington Post,

now HuffPo, who is now the
founder and CEO of Thrive
Global.

So we're going to bring
her in in a second.

But before that, I want to
bring in my co-host, Josh Macht,

my longtime friend
and colleague.

And Josh, I want to
check in with you.

You know, it's interesting,
somebody asked me

the other day, are
we always going

to check in with people, you
know, that every email we send
is sort of, how are you doing?
I hope you're OK.

And I think it's
a fair question.
Are we going to keep doing that?

The argument for
it is it's nice.

The argument
against-- it's email.

We're trying to get
through a lot of it.
So Josh.
I'm checking in with you.
How are you doing?
JOSHUA MACHT: I'm OK.

But it's a really
good question, Adi.

Yeah, do we continue--
because it is a nice thing

to be a sort of checked in
on and check in on someone.
You sort of feel--
and I'm doing OK.
This is week 9.

But I also wonder
how long we're going
to keep marking the weeks.
This just feels--
I'm not sure about that.
How about you?

ADI IGNATIUS: Yeah,
I'm still counting.

Now, for people who
are watching this,

put your comments in
the comment field.

Let us know who you
are, where you're from.

But most importantly, put in
your own questions for Arianna.

Because we'll
interview her, but we

want to get to a lot of
your questions as well.

Josh, the only other
thing on my mind
is just we're all starting--

or many of us are starting
to think about getting back

to work, getting
back in the office,
and what that will look like.

As I say that, though,
I realize that we

are kind of a unique subset,
the white-collar knowledge

business, whatever
you want to call it.

We've seen companies-- Capital
One won't be back in the office
until Labor Day.
Amazon is talking about October.

Google and Facebook are
saying their employees are
going to stay home until 2021.

They're finding that
work-at-home is effective,

that they don't need to be in
the offices to do what they do.

Now you think of the
disparity, and it's

a class disparity or
a work-type disparity,

or something like that, when
you think of all the people

who are on the front lines,
the so-called essentials.

And that number
is going to grow.

So we're going to have more
people out there working.

We're going to have
more people at risk.
We're all going to be at risk.

And I think, for
a while at least,

we're going to have
to accept more risk,
and just try to mitigate that.

So Josh, I don't know what
you're thinking is about that.

JOSHUA MACHT: I think
you're right, Adi.

I think that there's the
disparity part of it.
There's the fact that this is--

you know, this was a big
disruption, obviously,
for when we kind of all went in.

Now, as we reopen, that's also
this massive readjustment,
all these new issues.

I mean, some of
these things we're

going to be diving into with
our guests, which is terrific.

But I think we're only starting
to really contemplate just

how some parts of the population
are just hit so hard by this.

You and I, we really can kind of
work at home and be productive.

And again, it's going
to, in some ways,

be a big adjustment
for when we get back,

like figuring out how do we work
when we get back in the office.

ADI IGNATIUS: Yeah,
well I have colleagues

who are dying to get
back and colleagues

who would be happy to never
go back in the office.

So anyway, let's
bring in our guests.

Again, if you just joined
us, this is HBR Quarantined.

I'm Adi Ignatius,
editor-in-chief of HBR.
My co-host is Josh Macht.

Our special guest today is
Arianna Huffington, again,

the co-founder and the life
force behind the Huffington
Post.

Now is the founder/CEO
of Thrive Global,

which is a media
platform set up to help

us address the epidemic,
with stress and burnout.

So just before we go to
her, we created a TikTok

that I think touches on
one of Arianna's topics,

which is whether or
not we are getting
enough sleep to do us any good.

So Engineer Dave,
hit the TikTok.
[VIDEO PLAYBACK]

- Day 1 of not
getting enough sleep.
[R&B MUSIC]

Day 2 of not getting
enough sleep.

Day 4 of not getting
enough sleep?

(INCOHERENTLY) Week--
one week of not sleeping.
Wait, am I filming this?
[END PLAYBACK]

ADI IGNATIUS: All right,
Arianna, that was for you.
Welcome.
I'd love to know, where are you?

How have you been
managing your life
these past couple of months?

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON: Thank
you so much, Adi and Joshua.

And I actually love
starting with that question.

And let's keep
that ritual going.
I'm in Los Angeles.
I normally live in New York.

But I brought up my two
daughters here in LA.

So my two daughters and
my sister moved out here.

And this is week 9 for
us, as it is for you.

And Thrive-- the work has
been busier than ever,

because for every company now,
health and wellness have been

moved to the front burner,
and directly linked

to re-entry, to business
metrics, to everything
a company cares about.

And I must say it's been really
productive working from home
without distractions.

And we are waiting to hear
when our offices in New

York, and LA, and San
Francisco will open.
No plans yet.

JOSHUA MACHT: Arianna,
you know, a lot of people

sort of say to me that there's
just a low level now of stress
or anxiety that's just--
it's pervasive.
It's always there.

And I think, especially
for a lot of people--

I mean, sometimes,
for many people,
that's always been the case.

For people now, they're
feeling it more acutely.

Help us to think about how is
it that we can stay mentally

fit as we continue through this,
which is clearly going to be
this protracted period of time?

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON:
Well, the first thing

is we can't minimize the
upheaval and the pain
for many people.

I mean, you know, we are
among the lucky ones.

Just look at what's happening
with the loss of loved

ones, the loss of jobs,
the financial uncertainty.

So the first thing
is acknowledging
the grief and the loss.

But then, beyond
that, for me, this

is an incredible
opportunity to fix

a lot of the things that were
not working in the old world
that we left behind.

And if you think of it in
terms of flattening the curve,

I think there are other
curves we need to flatten.

And this is a time to start
working on that one of them

is on mental health,
stress, and burnout.

And as you know, mental
health had already

been established as a
crisis before the pandemic.

The World Health Organization
identified burnout

as a medical center
affecting workplaces.

And of course we also had the
increase in chronic diseases

like diabetes and hypertension,
which were all very
stress related.

So this is an
opportunity to look
at what were we doing wrong.

And I think one of the
things we were doing wrong--

and you know, that's why
we built to thrive to try
and address it--

was living our lives in this
breathless, frenetic, always-on

way, where we felt that we could
not disconnect because then we
would be left behind.

And that is fundamentally at the
heart of a lot of the problems
we're facing.

ADI IGNATIUS: Let me ask-- and
I don't mean to be disrespectful

at all-- but you created
this company, Thrive Global,

to deal with the problems
of stress and burnout.
What qualified you?

What made you feel like, OK,
you have the qualification

issues to communicate
insights on this topic?

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON: Well,
we have actually built
an amazing scientific board.

So it's not like I'm
coming up with a solution.

We have a great board with
the dean of the Stanford

School of Medicine, Dr. David
Agus, a lot of academics,

and people who have been
working from Harvard--

Charles Czeisler, who has been
working on sleep, Dr. Michelle

Williams, from the Harvard
School of Public Health.
So a lot of scientists.

And everything we're
doing is science-based.

That is a big redefining of
wellness priority for us,

to recognize that, in fact,
the way we have been living
our lives is unscientific.

It's actually not
validated by the data.

And in fact, the
Harvard Business Review

had a great piece on sleep-- you
mentioned sleep earlier-- based

on what McKinsey had done
on sleep and leadership.

So everything we put forward
is science-based, data-driven.

And what we are working to do
through our behavior change

products that we
launched is help people

through daily nudges,
daily microsteps,

to change behaviors, which as
we know is incredibly hard.

JOSHUA MACHT: What
about, for folks

who are managers and
leaders, what can

we do, especially to help
those who are already

feeling like they're just
at the end of the rope here.

They're juggling a
lot of work, family,
there's so many stresses.

How do you both sort of
spot that, especially
when we're all remote--

it feels sometimes like it's
difficult to really make

sure we're aware of
everyone on our teams--

but then also help people
through it as leaders?

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON: Well the
first thing is to model it.

We're finding in our work
with many leadership teams--

I was on a webinar, for
example, with 40 people

who are in the global management
committee that runs Accenture.

They have over
500,000 employees.

And they are
feeling overwhelmed.

So the first step
is, how can leaders

work with themselves so they're
not feeling overwhelmed?

Because if they are overwhelmed
and really stressed,

they're going to communicate
it to everyone around them.

And we recommend microsteps
that help them get
to the eye of the hurricane.

We have a whole new
Leadership Playbook
we work with with leaders.

And the theme is the
eye of the hurricane.

We are in a
metaphorical hurricane.

And if you look at the
hurricanes, the real ones,
there is always an eye.
There is a place of calm.

And how can leaders
get to that place?

There are little things
they can do every day that
help them get there.

And also there is a
mindset shift required.

The mindset shift
is to stop believing

that they need to be
always on in order

to be successful as
leaders, that they need

to be able to recharge
themselves to come up

with their best
ideas, their most
creative innovative solutions.

And that requires a different
way of managing their days.

And we have hundreds
of microsteps.

But they come down, again, to
the scientific foundational

importance of sleep
in order to recharge,

and also that it takes 60
seconds to course-correct
from stress during the day.

So taking the 60-second
breaks to breathe consciously,

to walk around, to remember
what you are grateful for

make a real direct difference
to our levels of stress

and to our levels of empathy
which, to your point, Josh,

is essential if we
are going to recognize
where our colleagues are.

ADI IGNATIUS: So let's stay
on the kind of practical tips

because I think everybody
can use them these days.

And I'm actually going to
go to a question that came
in from one of our viewers.

This is from Ellen
from the Netherlands.

But it's really the topic of
sleep, which Arianna, this is

a topic that you have
really championed,

that we're not
getting enough sleep.

So, simple question-- do you
have any tips for getting
to sleep after the workday?
ARIANNA HUFFINGTON: Yes.

The first tip is to pick
a time when you stop
consuming coronavirus news.
All of us want to be informed.

But if we keep consuming news
right up until we turn off

the light, we are going
to be too stressed and too
anxious about what's happening.

There is rarely any good
coronavirus news yet.
So declare a cutoff point.

Manage the notifications
on your phone

so that you don't constantly
get breaking news which,

coming from the media
world, I can assure
you is rarely breaking news.

And also take your phone and
charge it outside your bedroom
when you sleep.
That is incredibly important.

Because if you wake
up in the middle

of the night for
whatever reason,

you are going to be
tempted to go to your phone

if you can't go
right back to sleep.

I mean, we can all
identify with that.

And then the time for your sleep
is going to be interrupted.

And another thing as
well, working from home,

the truth is that
our work never ends.

So we need to kind of
relentlessly prioritize

what really has to be completed
by the end of the day,

and then get comfortable
with incompletions.

This is one of our microsteps
that really works for people.

Otherwise they can stay
up literally all night--
we all can--

getting things done, answering
emails, handling things.
JOSHUA MACHT: What about the--

so Arianna, everyone talks
about the wacky corona
dreams that they're having.

Friends and family
tell me they wake up

in sort of in the middle of
the night sometimes in a shock
or in a panic.
What do you make of all this?

I know I've had some
strange corona-- they're not

that strange, because
they're mostly

about just sort of
being trapped, or not

being able to move very well,
being constricted in some way.

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON: I
think the key thing is
to have a transition to sleep.

Those of us with children know
that when they were little,
we didn't just drop them in bed.

We had a whole transition,
where we gave them a bath,

and we put them in their
PJs, we sang them a lullaby,
we read them Goodnight Moon.

Well, we need to
have a transition

for ourselves,
especially during times
of extreme stress like this.

We actually partner
with Audible,

and launched a series
of free sleep solutions

that include a parody of
Goodnight Moon that I did,

called Goodnight Smartphone,
a sleep meditation with Diddy,

Sean Combs, that is
kind of amazing--

if you ever have trouble
sleeping, please download it--

and a lot of other things that
will help people for free,

be able to relax,
basically, and surrender

to sleep, which is what many
people have a hard time doing.

And then the dreams are going
to be less coronavirus-centered.

ADI IGNATIUS: So let me turn to
another question from a viewer.

This is from Ibrahim
from Antalya, Turkey.

The question is, how
can leaders become

more self-aware of themselves
and benefit from meditation,

or sleep, whatever,
to lead from within.

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON:
Great question.

The first thing is
a mindset shift.

And that's really what I am
optimistic about in terms
of the next normal.

We need to leave behind the idea
of a leader who was always on,

who never disconnected,
and bragged about it.

I mean, how many
times have we heard

leaders brag about how
little sleep they got,

or how they work 24/7,
ignoring all the science

and the data that shows that
if you actually don't take time

to sleep, you are less
effective, less productive,
less creative, less empathetic.

And I wrote a book, as you know,
called The Sleep Revolution.

And I have 50 pages of
scientific information

on the importance of
sleep for the brain.

So it's particularly
interesting that it affects
how we function mentally.

And that's why it's such a
key leadership precondition.

But we need to
change the culture.

The culture is still
not clear on that.

It goes back to the first
Industrial Revolution,

when we started revering
machines, and then software.

And of course the goal
with machines and software
is to minimize downtime.

But for us, for humans, for
the human operating system,
downtime is not a bug.
It's a feature.

When we remember
that, then we are

going to prioritize
it as leaders,

and recognize that we are much
better at dealing, especially

in a moment of crisis, with all
the challenges in front of us.

JOSHUA MACHT: For many
folks, we talk about some

of the upsides of
this whole isolation.

And to your point,
there's always

been these mental health issues,
and somewhat of a crisis,
as you pointed out.

But I guess I worry
that we're just

going to snap right back to
the old ways as soon as we--

even if reentry is
gradual, I sort of feel

like, at some point, we get back
to racing to catch that plane,
do those things.
It may be a long time from now.

But I mean, are you
thinking about how do we

create new habits now that
we take out of this crisis?

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON: Josh, this
is the most important question.

And actually I really
wish we would all

spend much more time
discussing that, and much less

time discussing when are
we going to be out of it,
because we don't really know.

So yes, I profoundly believe
that we can use this time
to build new habits.

It's exactly how you
are describing it.

And I'm really
excited about the work

we are doing with some of the
biggest companies in the world
to do just that.

With Walmart, we're working
both with our leadership

and with the associates on
the ground, in the stores.

We have produced a special
behavior change app for 100,000
distribution center associates.

Doing daily journeys on these
themes with the leadership.
We are working with Accenture.

We've launched an entire
mental resilience program

with Accenture, to all
their 5,000 employees

that we developed in
partnership with Stanford based

on the latest brain
research around the brain
and mental health.

And it's kind of
amazing how helpful

it has been to see
unprecedented engagement.

People really want to
address these issues.

And companies are
prioritizing it

in a way they
haven't done before.

JOSHUA MACHT: Well that's
really-- and sort of

a follow-up too,
because I'm curious,

with the burnout issue, it
feels like, at least in my life,

the context shifting
was so important, right?

The fact that we could
move around in some ways

always helps to
break up monotony.

And I'm just like,
what are we supposed

to do right now in the
sense where you just

don't have that ability to do
that kind of context-shifting?

If feels like we're even
more vulnerable to burnout.

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON: I don't
think the problem with burnout

has been primarily
context shifting.

I think the problem has been
being completely disconnected
from ourselves.

And I think we've all
been living our lives
in such a distracted way.

And of course social media and
our phones have not helped.

And so the priority
and the opportunity

now is to help us connect with
ourselves, with our own center,

and from that place deal with
all the challenges in front
of us.

It's actually a time to connect
with ancient wisdom also.

Whether you read the stoics, or
the Bhagavad Gita, or the Tao,

or any spiritual and
philosophical tradition,

it comes down to the
same truth, which

is that we all have that
place of strength, resilience,
wisdom, and peace in us.

But most of the time
we don't live there.

This is an opportunity
to tap into that place,

to get glimpses of that
place-- nobody lives there all
the time--
so that we know that we have it.
We have access to it.
And we can reconnect with that.

In frenetic times, as I'm
sure they're going to return--

as you said, rushing to get
a plane or meet a deadline--

but to know that we
have that place that we

can return to recharge and
reconnect with what matters.
JOSHUA MACHT: Do you--
oh, you're back, Adi.
Hey.
ADI IGNATIUS: I'm back.
Yeah, I disappeared for a while.

If you just joined us,
this is HBR Quarantined.

If you have questions
for Arianna Huffington

about stress, about burnout,
about dealing with anxiety

in this particular moment,
put them in the comment box
and we will try to get to them.

Actually, I do have
a question here.

This is from Cindy from
Detroit who's asking,

is there anything
we can do to help

reduce the anxiety that
our colleagues feel
about returning to work?

Like I said, some of us are
eager to get back in there.
Many aren't.

How do we ease the anxiety of
those who aren't so thrilled
about the prospect?

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON:
So first of all,

recognize that that anxiety
is based on the fact

that we still don't have
adequate testing, that we still

don't know fully who
has been infected
and who has antibodies.

So it's not like
a crazy anxiety.

Nevertheless, to
reduce that anxiety,

the key is to be as much as
you can in the present moment.

Anxiety is always
about the future.

And I have a saying
on my desk here,

by the French
philosopher Montaigne,

who said, "there were many
terrible things in my life,

but most of them
never happened."

So we need to remember that a
lot of the things we're anxious

for and about
actually don't happen.
They are negative fantasies.

And in that Thriving
Mind, the course

that we developed to Stanford,
Professor Leanne Williams

who developed it with
us has identified

eight different stress types,
anxiety types, depression
types, that she calls biotypes.

And we all are predisposed
to one or the other.

And when we understand what
is our dominant biotype,

it's easier to have tools and
techniques to deal with it.

Like one of them, for
example, is negative bias.

And that's somebody who
tends to look at the negative

always in terms of what they
predict about the future.

Another is threat response,
when somebody's mind
is in a perpetual alarm mode.

And that, of course, can
be incredibly exhausting.

But identifying these
different biotypes--

and we have a lot of
information on that

also available on
ThriveGlobal.com

can help people
become more self-aware

and kind of recognize the
signs when they come up.

ADI IGNATIUS: My wife's
mother had a great saying

that we often refer
to, which sort

of echoes the Montaigne
quote, which is, there's
no use in worrying twice.

You know, if something bad
happens, worry about it.

But the anticipation--
there's no use worrying twice.

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON: The
anticipation is worse.
It's often worse.

Because there's nothing
you can do about it.

At least when something bad
happens, we can take action.
JOSHUA MACHT: Yeah.

Although, right
now, I feel like we

doe that a lot of the
time with our thoughts.
So it's really hard to hold off.

ADI IGNATIUS: I
mean, in a sense,

Josh, I think what
you're saying is,
we sort of miss the commute.
I never thought I'd say that.

But there's something
about the commute,

or some of those rituals
about, I don't know,

how you move in and out
of offices, that give you

that downtime, or give you
that sort of scene change,

where it's not just
day after day after day

that we're efficient
but it's monotonous.
We kind of miss those commutes.

JOSHUA MACHT:
Yeah, a little bit.

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON: But
you know, after all, you
are both tremendous readers.

So this is also an
amazing opportunity

to read things that actually
strengthen us at this time.

I mean, I've always
had, on my nightstand,

Marcus Aurelius's
Meditations, which I think
is the best book on leadership.

But now I literally read at
least a few pages every day.
Because there he was.

He was the emperor
of Rome for 19 years.

And for 14 of those, he dealt
with a horrific plague as well

as invasions, betrayals, and
everything that could go wrong.

And yet he managed
to find that place

that he called
the inner citadel,

and go there, and regularly
kind of refuel himself.

And I feel we have so
many incredible examples

from history of people
who got through at times

of tremendous trial
stronger than before.

And this is what we
can go to at this time
to also strengthen ourselves.

JOSHUA MACHT: Yeah,
no, it's true, Arianna.

But at first, when we kind of
entered this, reading, for me,
was a little difficult actually.
I was distracted.

Now, going into someone's world
like that or reading a novel

is amazing, because it's
the closest thing to travel
to get out of where we are.

ADI IGNATIUS: Yeah, so Arianna,
those are good book tips.

I don't have all
of those books you
mentioned on my night table.

I do have Goodnight
Moon, but that's

because my granddaughter was
just here for the weekend.
ARIANNA HUFFINGTON: [CHUCKLES]

ADI IGNATIUS: But
I want to-- so we

have a segment that we do each
episode called "Here Today
or Here to Stay."

And Josh, you want
to tee that up?
JOSHUA MACHT: Sure.

So the thing that
I find right now

is I am probably
walking more than ever.

So it's probably been
one of the things that I

take advantage of right now,
a couple times a day at least.

And it's great because you
can have meetings with people,
you can walk.

And it feels, at least as
the weather gets nicer,
it feels amazing.

And it's something
that was really

difficult to squeeze in our
old life, in the old world.

So I am hopeful this is
something we carry forward.

ADI IGNATIUS: Ah,
yes, the walks.
I love the walks.

I don't know if the walks
will survive the transition.

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON:
But you know,

can we do everything we can
that they survive [INAUDIBLE]..

Because it's not like
we are powerless.

It's really back
to what Josh said

about building these
healthy habits,

realizing how much we love
them, and then taking them
with us in the new world.
JOSHUA MACHT: Yeah.

Yeah, Adi, I think we
need to make them survive.
ADI IGNATIUS: OK, all right.
So we're just about out of time.

I may look for one more
question from a viewer.
Ah, OK.

This is one from
Rajeev from Bangladesh.

What should I do to stay calm as
I look for a new job right now?

ARIANNA HUFFINGTON:
So thank you so
much for asking that question.

Because we are talking about
philosophical traditions

and how do we
strengthen ourselves.

We need to recognize
